title: STUDY THEME,  The Humanity of Jesus. Part 25
devotional:
How do we become cross bearers?

We must deny ourselves

What does it men to deny yourself? Many people think that to deny yourself means that we must feel bad about ourselves, we must loathe ourselves, we need to suffer from a poor self image. However, those who think this way are unable to deny themselves. Denying yourself is an expression of security not insecurity, it is a volitional choice of our wills, not an emotional response to the world around us. When we fall into the trap of equating a low self-image with self-denial we are doing the complete opposite to what we think we are doing. People who suffer from chronic self-image problems can become self-obsessed and self-centred, which in turns prevents self-denial.

The Greek word for deny is arneomai means, disown, renounce, refuse, not to accept, to reject, to refuse something offered, it carries the idea of making a volitional choice. It is best illustrated in the words of Philippians 2:6-8

'Who being in very nature God, did not consider equality with God something to be grasped. But made himself nothing, taking the very nature of a servant, being made in human likeness. And being found in the appearance of a man he humbled himself, and became obedient to death even death on a cross.'

To deny yourself is to choose being a servant over having a position of authority. To deny yourself is to choose humility over pride. To deny yourself is to choose to obey the will of God irrespective of the personal cost and pain. To deny yourself is an expression of self acceptance and contentment.

We must understand the true source of life.

Look at what Jesus said. ‘For whoever wants to save their life will lose it, but whoever loses their life for me will find it. What good will it be for someone to gain the whole world, yet forfeit their soul? Or what can anyone give in exchange for their soul?

Jesus says four things about life, in these verses.

1 Whoever desires to save his life will lose it.

2 Whoever loses his life for Christ's sake will find it.

3 What profit is it to a man if he gains the whole world, and loses his own soul.

4 What will a man give in exchange for his life?

It’s important to realise that in this passage, Jesus is addressing believers, not unbelievers.

So what does it mean to loose your life and save your life?

All believers have eternal life. However, only self-denying believers will realise the full potential of eternal life (John 10:10). A 'saved life' is the glory of a life lived for God.

To loose one's life is to play it safe; it is to decide against the way of the cross and its confrontation with the status quo. It is to decide for what is safe, it is a deep concern for self-interest. "Survival at all costs," is a flawed philosophy by which to live. 'Be faithful to Christ no matter what the cost,' is the philosophy Jesus' disciples came to live by. We are made in such away, that when we live a self-obsessed life, something with in us dies. We have been made to live life for the benefit of others, which is only possible when we live a cross shaped life.

"Jesus is not anti-our-life; he is anti-preoccupation-with-our-life" (Bruner, 593)

You will have right priorities.

Jesus put other people first.

On the cross, He died for the sins of the world.

On the cross, He looked after those He loved.

On the cross, He forgave those who hurt Him.

On the cross, He demonstrated the heart of God.

The cross we carry should be an echo of His cross.
prayer: Prayer, Father help me to value the cross you want me to take up.
